item.title: Visual Studio Tricks I Wish I Knew From the Start
item.description: Debugging Perfect Forwarders in Visual Studio IDE Visual Studio tends to give really bad error messages for perfect forwarders. For example, if I give the wrong arguments to std::vector’s emplace_back, I will get sent to a line in xmemory.h, and not the the line of code I wrote. Previously, I debugged this by deliberately raising a warning every time I used a perfect forwarder, so I can easily go back and correct the line if needed.
